Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Sparse-sampling inference for functional proteomics, metabolomics and ionomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Northeastern University is awarded a grant by the NSF Faculty Early Career
Development (CAREER) Program to develop statistical and computational
tools for functional proteomics, metabolomics and ionomics. The
proposed research will address three inter-related aims: (1) Accurate
identifications and quantifications of proteins, metabolites and ions
from high-throughput experiments, which generate sparse data in form
of mass and nuclear magnetic resonance spectra; (2) Joint
interpretation and integration of these sparse heterogeneous datasets;
and (3) Optimal design of global and targeted follow-up experiments.
The proposed program is innovative in that it closely accounts for the
biological and technological characteristics of proteomics,
metabolomics and ionomics. As the result, it will increase the
sensitivity, accuracy, and scope of interpretation of the
investigations. The utility of the developed methods of statistical
inference, and of the associated open-source software, will be
demonstrated on functional screens of S. cerevisiae, which integrate
heterogeneous transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic and ionomic
datasets.

The proposed program will contribute to bridging the communication gap
between biologists, chemists and statisticians. The project will promote the
computational thinking, and the appropriate use of statistical
methodology, by making available case studies that are relevant to the
user community, by offering interdisciplinary tutorials and short
courses at scientific meetings and interdisciplinary courses at
Purdue, and by providing mentoring for graduate and undergraduate students across
departments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PI Olga Vitek has completed the project CAREER: Sparse-sampling inference for functional proteomics, metabolomics and ionomics. The project aimed for (1) accurate identifications and quantifications of analytes in mass spectrometry-based experiments, (2) joint interpretation and integration of heterogeneous datasets, and (3) optimal design of global and targeted experiments.


The outcomes of the project were in line with the goals above. They consisted of statistical methods, open-source software implementation, documentation and case studies, as well as educational materials for practitioners with limited statistical background.


For the first objective, the outcome of the project was a general and flexible family of linear mixed models, applicable to mass spectrometry-based experiments with complex designs. The approach was implemented in open-source, R-based software MSstats. For imaging mass spectrometry, the outcome was a series of methods for efficient spectral processing, and novel approaches for spatial classification and segmentation of mass spectrometric images. The methods were implemented in an open-source R package Cardinal. Both MSstats and Cardinal were extensively evaluated for accuracy, scalability and ease of use, and were used in numerous applications. In 2017, both tools were among the 20% of the most downloaded software packages on the project Bioconductor.


For the second objective, the outcome of the project was a series of statistical methods that interpret quantitative mass spectrometry­-based experiments in the context of known biochemical reactions and functional annotations, available e.g. in public repositories such as KEGG. The project demonstrated that this approach can increase the statistical power of discovering new associations between abundances of the analytes under the conditions of interest, and can help make hypotheses regarding their causal relationships.

For the third objective, one outcome of the project was a systematic framework for comparing strategies of acquisition of quantitative mass spectrometric measurements, for verifying that the measurement system and the assays are suitable for the intended purpose, and for selecting the type and number for biological replicates, while accounting for the possible sources of variation.  Another outcome of the project was a novel Bayesian active learning approach to experimental design. The approach selects a set of targeted perturbations that maximize the expected information content in the planned study, and optimizes the statistical inference of biomolecular networks under the constraints of experimental feasibility and cost.

Finally, the group actively disseminated the results of the project to the mass spectrometry practitioners, who are the potential users of the methods and tools. The group co-organized or co-taught numerous short courses that discuss the statistical aspects of experimental design and analysis, the key concepts relevant to mass spectrometry-based experiments, and their implementations. The information was also disseminated through the research publications, through oral and poster presentations at conferences, through the websites describing the software and the case studies, as well as through dedicated discussion groups where users can submit questions and receive feedback. The project presented numerous interdisciplinary training opportunities for PhD students in statistics.
